content:
‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This puzzle is very good.

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: These are the type of problems we need in reverse : )
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

It took me looking through multiple validation examples to understand the problem and how I was expected to solve it. I think it confused me that the statement says: "and needs you to define the number of rooms that he can have."  It is explained on the section describing the Output, but it gives two conflicting goals and I initially overlooked the Output description.

Another possible problem is that for the input 117, a valid Output given the constraints would be 9 and 6, and it would not be categorically wrong by the way you defined the problem. However, you'd need a different approach to get to this answer. It may even be a better answer if you consider the goal as having the fewest rooms or greater average room size instead of the largest room possible each time you use the remaining surface to make a new room.

A similar clash exists:
https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/28428c62f4e0ba75d89e184ab78f6a5627daa

Please use another idea for your contribution.

Also remember that

* each test should be similar to its corresponding validator, but they should still be different.

* a write statement should be added to the stub generator.

Thanks.

I have kept the idea of the powers of two but inverted the logic. Given the final sum, you now need to find the roots used to reach the final sum.
I think the new statement makes it for a better clash of code with enough data to make people think a little more, while still keeping it simple enough for blind and fast modes.

I also fixed my stub generator and all the validators to fit the rules.
Thanks for your feedback

Hi bucke, thank you for your message.
I have adapted the goal description.
Concerning your second paragraph, it is clearly stated that the client always wants the biggest possible room. For the example 117, there is only one solution that fulfills this request : the biggest room is 100sqm (10x10). Then you still have 17sqm that can be split into 16sqm (4x4) and 1sqm (1x1). The only possible answer is indeed 10,4,1
I have an issue, I do not find any way in the interface to make it public and publish the contribution :o can anyone help in this subject ?
thank you for your approval :) Yes I think it is indeed a good problem for reverse (I actually started thinking about it for reverse only, as it's my preferred way to play clash of code ! :P)

Interesting idea! üëçüèª

Goal
* Please delete the last paragraph, which is no longer relevant.

Output
* Please change "the next biggest" to "a", and then add ", sorted in descending order" after "in the house".

Stub generator
* Please change "N" to "Surface".

Thanks.

thanks for your fast feedback again üôè
I have made the adjustments as requested, most of them were stuff from the first version indeed ,sorry for that !
